author: Sophia Lavcanski
title: Maden in der Mülltonne bei Sommer-Hitze: So lässt sich das Ungeziefer bekämpfen
text:
Maden in der Mülltonne bei Sommer-Hitze: So lässt sich das Ungeziefer bekämpfen
In den heißen Sommermonaten haben viele mit einem Problem zu kämpfen: Maden in der Mülltonne. Doch es gibt einfache Maßnahmen, um die kleinen Larven wieder loszuwerden.
Wenn die Temperaturen steigen, vermehren sich Insekten besonders schnell – auch rund um den Hausmüll. Fliegen nutzen die Hitze, um ihre Eier in den Tonnen abzulegen. Daraus entwickeln sich innerhalb kurzer Zeit weiße Maden. Diese treten meist in großer Zahl auf und sorgen trotz ihrer Harmlosigkeit bei vielen für Ekel. Doch wie lässt sich das verhindern?
Maden vorbeugen: Mit einfachen Maßnahmen den Befall verhindern
Um Maden erst gar keine Chance zu geben, sollte der Müll regelmäßig entsorgt werden. Eine wöchentliche Leerung der Tonne und anschließende Reinigung kann schon viel ausrichten.
Wichtig ist außerdem, dass der Deckel immer gut verschlossen bleibt. Wer noch mehr Schutz möchte, kann eine Gummidichtung am Deckelrand anbringen oder einen speziellen Deckel für Biotonnen verwenden.
Müll trocken halten – Maden mögen es feucht und warm
Da sich Maden besonders in feuchten und warmen Umgebungen wohlfühlen, sollte der Müll möglichst trocken bleiben. Vor allem im Biomüll wird Feuchtigkeit schnell zum Problem. Der Restmüll ist meist recht luftdicht in Plastiktüten eingepackt, wodurch wenig ein und ausdringt. echo24.de erklärt, wann Müll in eine Tüte gehört und wann nicht.
Laut „GEO“ helfen beim Trockenhalten von Mülltonnen Materialien wie Zeitungspapier, Sägespäne, trockenes Gras oder Heu, um Feuchtigkeit zu binden. All diese Materialien dürfen auch in die Biotonne. Auch der Standort der Tonne spielt eine Rolle: Sie sollte an einem kühlen, trockenen Platz stehen.
So wird man Maden wieder los – einfache Hausmittel im Einsatz
Hat sich der Nachwuchs der Fliegen bereits breitgemacht oder war die Vorsorge nicht erfolgreich, gibt es laut „GEO“ einfache Hausmittel gegen Maden. Eine Möglichkeit: Kalk in die Tonne streuen. Der entzieht den Maden Feuchtigkeit. Auch Gesteinsmehl kann verwendet werden.
Wer eine Sprühflasche hat, kann auf zwei bewährte Mischungen zurückgreifen: Entweder Wasser mit mehreren Esslöffeln Essig oder Essigessenz, oder eine Mischung aus einem Liter abgekochtem Wasser mit einem Esslöffel Pfeffer. Beide Lösungen lassen sich direkt auf die Maden sprühen.
Selbst gebaute Mückenfalle gegen neue Eier
Um zu verhindern, dass neue Fliegen ihre Eier ablegen, empfiehlt „GEO“ den Bau einer einfachen Mückenfalle: Dafür zwei Teile Wasser mit drei Teilen Fruchtsaft, einem Teil Essig und einigen Tropfen Spülmittel mischen. Die Mischung in ein Glas geben und direkt neben der Biotonne aufstellen. Das Spülmittel reduziert die Oberflächenspannung – Fliegen, die auf der Flüssigkeit landen, ertrinken sofort.

author: Ellitoral.com
title: Alerta por tormentas fuertes y posible caída de granizo en Santa Fe y 12 provincias de Argentina
text:
Se espera que la semana cierre con malas condiciones del clima en diferentes zonas del país, por lo que el Servicio Meteorológico Nacional (SMN) relanzó un alerta por tormentas fuertes con posible caída de granizo y ráfagas.
El aviso amarillo del Servicio Meteorológico afecta a los departamentos de 9 de Julio, Vera, General Obligado, San Cristóbal, San Justo y San Javier.
Se espera que la semana cierre con malas condiciones del clima en diferentes zonas del país, por lo que el Servicio Meteorológico Nacional (SMN) relanzó un alerta por tormentas fuertes con posible caída de granizo y ráfagas.
De esta manera, el SMN mantenía un alerta amarillo que rige este viernes en zonas de la Ciudad de Buenos Aires, el conurbano, el centro, norte y costa de la provincia de Buenos Aires; y regiones de Santa Fe, Córdoba, Entre Ríos, Corrientes, Misiones, Chaco, Formosa, Santiago del Estero, La Rioja, Catamarca, Tucumán y Salta.
En lo que respecta al territorio santafesino, el aviso de nivel amarillo afecta a los departamentos de 9 de Julio, Vera, General Obligado, San Cristóbal, San Justo y San Javier.
De acuerdo con el reporte del SMN, en zonas con alerta amarillo, “el área será afectada por tormentas, algunas de las cuales podrían ser localmente fuertes o severas. Estas tormentas estarán acompañadas de ráfagas intensas, ocasional caída de granizo, actividad eléctrica significativa y abundante caída de agua en cortos períodos".
Se prevén valores de precipitación acumulada entre 30 y 50 mm, pudiendo ser superados en forma puntual.
En zonas de Santa Fe, Corrientes, Chaco, Formosa, Santiago del Estero, Catamarca y Tucuman, el aviso subía a alerta naranja. En este caso, “el área será afectada por lluvias y tormentas fuertes. Las mismas podrán estar acompañadas por actividad eléctrica significativa, caída de granizo, ráfagas intensas y, especialmente, abundante caída de agua en cortos períodos".
Se prevén valores de precipitación acumulada entre 50 y 90 mm, pudiendo ser superados en forma puntual, especialmente en el Este de Formosa, Este de Chaco y Noroeste de Corrientes donde los valores podrían estar cercanos a los 150 mm.

author: Spencer German
title: Cleveland Browns Star Denzel Ward Sets Critical Expectation For Team's Future
text:
Another Browns Star Sets Critical Expectation For Team's Future
For the first time in his career, [Cleveland Brown](https://www.si.com/nfl/team/cleveland-browns) star defensive end Myles Garrett spoke the unthinkable, suggesting that playing somewhere else could be a possibility if the team's offseason goals don't align with his personal goals.
For Garrett that goal is winning, and if the organization decides a rebuild is the path forward, he may not want to stick around to be part of it. On Thursday, cornerback Denzel Ward echoed, at least some of, his fellow defensive star's sentiments.
"I'm ready to win as well," asserted Ward. "I know Myles is too. We competitors and winners and we just looking to try to find a way to get to the top. Obviously not have the losing season like we have now. We just looking for, how to get there."
Ward didn't quite go so far as saying he could envision himself playing elsewhere if the team doesn't execute a plan that is centered around retooling rather than rebuilding like Garrett did. He also didn't demand to see the team's offseason plan after a disastrous 2024 campaign wraps up. He will, however, take a peak.
"When they show Myles [the plan], I'll just look over Myles shoulder and see what the plan is," Ward said with a laugh. I'm ready to go forward with it, whatever it is."
While the Browns season overall hasn't gone even remotely close to how any expected, Ward has been a bright spot of a 3-12 team. In many respects he's having his best season of his career since being drafted No. 4 overall in 2018. The three-time Pro Bowler is leading the league in pass breakups with 19. He's also snared two interceptions forced and recovered a fumble and accumulated 39 tackles.
Like Myles, Ward is very much in the prime of his career, but thriving for a team that is going no where fast right now. That pair of stars hope to put their efforts to good use sooner rather than later. Their voices also carry a lot of weight, and tend to align with the rest of their defensive teammates. As a unit there seems to be a belief that they can correct things without a complete tear down.
"I think the biggest thing is, everybody just wanna win," reiterated Ward. "We all competitors out here, nobody wants to have a losing season and lose the majority of our games. So our biggest thing is trying to find a way to win and however we gotta get to that, we gotta work hard and try to get there."
Cleveland has two weeks to get through before the organization's brass will get to work on mapping out whatever the plan is for the team's future. Whatever it is, it could dictate the future of two of the team's biggest stars.

author: Business Standard
title: Over 30,000 TCS workers affected by TDS errors; Tax dept sends notices | Company News - Business Standard
text: TCS has a TDS problem. Numerous employees at Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) have been issued demand notices by the income tax department due to discrepancies in tax deducted at source (TDS) claims. According to a report from The Times of India, between 30,000 and 40,000 employees received these notices, with the tax demands ranging from Rs 50,000 to over Rs 1 lakh, depending on their seniority within the company. The problem is reportedly believed to have stemmed from a software error that resulted in TDS claims not being properly updated on the income-tax portal.These notices, sent out on September 9 under Section 143(1) of the Income Tax Act, indicated that there was no record of the full payments made by employees for the March quarter of FY24. Chartered Accountant Himank Singla also commented on the situation through his post on X, explaining that many TCS employees were receiving tax demands for the assessment year 2024-25 due to incorrect TDS updates on the department’s portal, leading to withheld refunds.The notices raised concerns among employees, as they highlighted discrepancies between the TDS claims made by individuals and the data available with the tax department.The company has send an internal communication advising employees not to take any action on the demands until further instructions were provided, The Times of India reported. TCS also informed its employees that it had notified the tax authorities and was working toward resolving the issue quickly.In a separate internal message, TCS communicated that the tax authorities had provided clarification and that they would be reprocessing the tax returns, after which the TDS information would align with Form 26AS issued by the income tax department and Form 16 Part A issued by TCS.TCS added 25k employees in first quarter of FY25Business Standard reported in July that TCS saw a net headcount increase of 5,452 employees in the first quarter of FY25, bringing the company’s total workforce to 606,998. This marked the first headcount growth for TCS after three consecutive quarters of decline. In the same quarter, TCS hired 11,000 freshers, with Chief Human Resource Officer Milind Lakkad noting that a portion of these hires were freshers whose onboarding had been delayed from the previous financial year. He further stated that there was no remaining backlog from the previous year and that all new hires moving forward would be fresh recruits offered positions this year.TCS was also noted as the first company, following Accenture, to report a net increase in its headcount, with Accenture having added 7,882 employees by the end of the third quarter of FY24, bringing its total workforce to 750,200..storycontent div {margin:10px 0;}

author: Clay Moden
title: The BEST Northern Lights Photos From New York State
text: The BEST Northern Lights Photos From New York State It was a gorgeous night to see the Northern Lights over portions of New York State and we caught a few great photos of the moment that included the moon! The cold and crisp air of the fall is here and the smell of leaves is in the air! There may not be a better time to live in New York State. This time of the year is the payoff to the long, hot and humid, summer. But there was an added bonus this week as the Norther Lights were visible across much go the Empire State. [READ MORE: New Nasty Viruses Found In New York State](https://wyrk.com/nasty-viruses-found-in-these-items-in-new-york-state/) As the sun was setting over our home in Western New York, I remembered that the lights were going to be seen from our area and was able to get a few quick shots off the lights. The interesting part is that when I looked with the naked eye, I could not really see the lights. However, a quick look at the gallery in my phone and WOW! The colors were spectacular. You can even see the stars and the moon beyond the silhouette of the trees. Northern Lights Dazzle Over New York State Gallery Credit: Clay Moden We truly are blessed to live in a state with so much beauty! I can only imagine what the lights may have looked like in the more rural areas of the state and from the peaks of the Adirondack Mountains. As the long weekend approaches, we are looking at a few more clear and crisp days! Below is another natural event that I was able to get from my trail camera in Western New York late last spring.

author: @WEAU13News
title: Efforts continue in Madison to expand Medicaid coverage for postpartum care; the cap currently at two months
text:
Efforts continue in Madison to expand Medicaid coverage for postpartum care; the cap currently at two months
EAU CLAIRE, Wis. (WEAU) - A bill to expand Medicaid coverage for post partum care from two months to a full year passed the Wisconsin Senate Tuesday.
“Overwhelmingly in the senate, it was 32 - 1,” said Republican State Senator Jesse James. “This is one of the most larger bipartisan bills that we’ve passed.”
Mothers like Cortney Nicholson who have just given birth and are in that window of time for postpartum complications could soon be further covered for medical care needed. She enjoyed her afternoon with her weeks-old baby. This is her second child, but she still recalls how difficult it was dealing with the not-so expected post birth experience.
“When I look at the two months that Medicaid covers, that’s just barely nicking the surface,” said Nicholson. “With this being my second birth, with the first one, I wasn’t healed even into twelve weeks.”
Mothers around the Chippewa Valley shared this sentiment.
“You need support all along to a year, sometimes even longer. But, to go to a year is amazing,” said Iris Casey, a mother of one and business owner of Mother Essence. She uses her business to help other mothers through postpartum by providing meals and helping with whatever a mother may need. “That whole journey myself led me to support other moms so they don’t have to go through something similar.”
“When they say it takes a village to raise a kid, they absolutely mean it,” said Paige Drobot, a mother of two and a working doula. “I mainly focus on the actual birthing portion, but they do still reach out to me afterward.”
Dr. Christina Kramer with Oakleaf Clinics has worked as an OBGYN for decade. She, along with the rest of the mothers that work with mothers in postpartum, sees and at times feel the need for all the coverage and support needed for the post birth phase of a mother’s life.
“There’s a lot of physical, emotional, psychological changes in the postpartum window. Postpartum mood disorders are extremely common. Up to 1 in 8 women experience some version,” said Dr. Kramer. “The process of pregnancy takes 9 to 10 months to occur. And, postpartum recovery takes as long.”
Dr. Kramer said she had also seen patients not keep up with care because of financial restraints and the two month limit on Medicaid coverage for post partum care in Wisconsin.
“I want to take care of the patient, but financial costs can be a burden for a lot of our patients, which is not ideal,” said Dr. Kramer.
The bill will still need to clear the assembly before getting to Governor Ever’s desk.
There is help for mothers in the Chippewa Valley:
Mama Bear Family Care, on Facebook, they also have an expo coming up on August 2nd in Eau Claire.
